 Temp. Cite: [2015] F.T.R. TBEd. OC.031 
 
 
 
 The Minister of Citizenship and Immigration (applicant) v. Venera Demurova (respondent) 
 
 (T-140-15; 2015 FC 872) 
 
 
 
 Indexed As: Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration) v. Demurova 
 
 
 
 Federal Court 
 
 Shore, J. 
 
 July 16, 2015. 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
 
 A Citizenship Judge granted Canadian citizenship to Demurova, a Russian citizen who became a permanent resident in 2008. In applying the physical presence test found in Re Pourghasemi, the Citizenship Judge found that Demurova was physically present in Canada for 1,093 days, and that a shortfall of two days of the minimal requirement of 1,095 days of physical presence was not significant. The Minister of Citizenship and Immigration applied for judicial review, submitting that the Citizenship Judge erred in the application of the strict physical presence test to determine whether the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act was met. 
 
 
 
 The Federal Court granted the application. "A Citizenship Judge is not entitled to simply waive the requirement of physical presence, as this would run contrary to the purpose of the Act ... . Moreover, this Court has found that a Citizenship Judge's 'blending' of the citizenship test constitutes an error of law". Further, allowing the Citizenship Judge's reasoning to stand would render s. 5(4) of the Act redundant. 
 
 
 
 Aliens - Topic 2525 
 
 Naturalization - Qualifications - Residence - See paragraphs 1 to 27. 
 
 
 
 Counsel: 
 
 Yaël Levy, for the applicant. 
 
 
 
 Solicitors of Record: 
 
 William F. Pentney, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Montreal, Quebec, for the applicant. 
 
 
 
 This application for judicial review was heard at Montreal, Quebec, on July 15, 2015, before Shore, J., of the Federal Court, who delivered the following judgment and reasons, dated July 16, 2015. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 .................................................. 
 
 
 
 I.  
 Overview

[1] 
   
 Shore, J. 
 : A Citizenship Judge is not entitled to simply waive the requirement of physical presence, as this would run contrary to the purpose of the  
 Citizenship Act 
 , RSC 1985, c C 29 [Act] ( 
FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED). Moreover, this Court has found that a Citizenship Judge's "blending" of the citizenship test constitutes an error of law ( 
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED). 
 
 
 
 II.  
 Background

[2] 
  The Minister challenges a decision dated December 31, 2014, rendered by a Citizenship Judge, granting Canadian citizenship to the Respondent, pursuant to subsection 72(1) of the  
 Immigration and Refugee Protection Act 
 , SC 2001, c 27.

[3] 
  The Respondent is a citizen of Russia who became a permanent resident of Canada on March 17, 2008.

[4] 
  The Respondent filed an application for citizenship on July 25, 2011. The relevant time period for the purposes of determining the Respondent's residency in accordance with paragraph 5(1)( 
 c 
 ) of the Act runs from July 25, 2007 to July 25, 2011.

[5] 
  On February 25, 2013, the Respondent attended an interview with a citizenship officer. The officer prepared a File Preparation and Analysis Template [FPAT] and placed it on file for consideration by the Citizenship Judge.

[6] 
  On December 29, 2014, the Respondent appeared before the Citizenship Judge. 
 
 
 
 III.  
 Impugned Decision

[7] 
  In the impugned decision, the Citizenship Judge considers the concerns raised by the citizenship officer in the FPAT, which include the observation of a two-day shortfall from the required minimal 1,095 days of presence in Canada, an undeclared re-entry stamp to Canada dated April 10, 2009, an undeclared entry/exit stamp from Turkey, and other credibility concerns relating to the Respondent's residence and employment history.

[8] 
  First, the Citizenship Judge finds that a shortfall of two days of the minimal requirement of 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada is not significant.

[9] 
  Second, the Citizenship Judge is satisfied that apart from the undeclared seven day trip to Cuba in 2009, the Respondent's passport entries support her declarations.

[10] 
  Third, the Citizenship Judge finds that the Respondent's trip to Turkey is inconsequential to her number of days of presence in Canada because it occurred during the Respondent's declared 61-day trip to Russia. The Citizenship Judge also notes that this ambiguity was clarified by the Respondent in her Residence Questionnaire, at question 7.

[11] 
  Fourth, the Citizenship Judge is satisfied that the Respondent's explanations for her absences during the relevant period are credible and supported by the evidence.

[12] 
  The Citizenship Judge ultimately finds that: 
 
 
 
 [T]he Applicant told her story in a forthright manner and was able to clearly explain the concerns raised by the agent in the FPAT. She did not give me any reasons to doubt her declarations. Furthermore, I gave particular weight to her travel documents which, along with the [Integrated Customs and Enforcement System] report, confirm her oral testimony. And, I note that she presented Notices of Assessment from Revenue Canada (except for 2010 when she was away as declared) and these also corroborate her oral and written statements. 
 
 
 
 (Impugned decision, Certified Tribunal Record, at p 14)

[13] 
  Finally, the Citizenship Judge concludes that the Respondent meets the physical presence test enunciated in  
 Pourghasemi (Re) 
 , [1993] FCJ 232 [ 
 Pourghasemi 
 ]. 
 
 
 
 IV. Legislative Provision

[15] 
  The Respondent submits the following issues to the Court: 
 
 
 
 a) Did the Citizenship Judge err in the application of the strict physical presence test to determine whether the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)( 
 c 
 ) of the Act was met? 
 
 
 
 b) Did the Citizenship Judge fail to adequately assess the evidence resulting in unreasonable finding of fact? 
 
 
 
 VI.  
 Standard of Review

[16] 
  A Citizenship Judge's findings in respect of whether the residency requirements for the purposes of paragraph 5(1)( 
 c 
 ) of the Act are met are questions of mixed fact and law that are reviewable on the standard of reasonableness ( 
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED).

[17] 
  As such, the highly discretionary nature of the Citizenship Judge's decision attracts considerable deference from this Court ( 
FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED). 
 
 
 
 VII.  
 Analysis

[18] 
  Paragraph 5(1)( 
 c 
 ) of the Act provides that citizenship applicants bear the onus of demonstrating that they have accumulated at least three years of residence in Canada - or 1,095 days - during the relevant four-year period.

[19] 
  This Court's jurisprudence has recognized that Citizenship Judges are entitled to choose from among the three accepted citizenship tests ( 
FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED).

[20] 
  The Court may not intervene unless the chosen citizenship test was applied in an unreasonable manner ( 
FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED).

[21] 
  The physical presence test provided in  
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED, is more restrictive than the qualitative residency tests elaborated in  
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED, as it requires a quantitative assessment of the number of days the Respondent has physically spent in Canada ( 
FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED).

[22] 
  In the case at hand, in applying the physical presence test found in  
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED, the Citizenship Judge found that the Respondent was physically present in Canada for 1,093 days (Impugned Decision, Certified Tribunal Record, at pp 13 and 15).

[23] 
  This is an unreasonable outcome which warrants the Court's intervention.

[24] 
  A Citizenship Judge is not entitled to simply waive the requirement of physical presence, as this would run contrary to the purpose of the Act ( 
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED). Moreover, this Court has found that a Citizenship Judge's "blending" of the citizenship test constitutes an error of law ( 
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED).

[25] 
  Justice Donald J. Rennie's reasoning in  
FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED, sheds light on Parliament's intent in legislating the residency requirements found in paragraph 5(1)( 
 c 
 ) of the Act: 
 
 
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED

[26] 
  Furthermore, as pointed out by Justice Peter B. Annis in  
FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED allowing the Citizenship Judge's reasoning to stand would render subsection 5(4) of the Act redundant: 
 
 
 
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED
 
 
 
 VIII.  
 Conclusion

[27] 
  For the reasons above, the Minister's application for judicial review is allowed.

[28] 
  The Court observes that the Respondent may re-apply for citizenship if she so wishes. 
 
 
 
 JUDGMENT

[29] 
   
 THIS COURT'S JUDGMENT is that 
  the application for judicial review is granted. There is no serious question of general importance to be certified. 
 
 
 
 Application granted. 
 
 
 
 Editor: E. Joanne Oley 
 
 
 
 [End of document]

[21] 
  The physical presence test provided in  
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED, is more restrictive than the qualitative residency tests elaborated in  
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED, as it requires a quantitative assessment of the number of days the Respondent has physically spent in Canada ( 
FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED).

[22] 
  In the case at hand, in applying the physical presence test found in  
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED, the Citizenship Judge found that the Respondent was physically present in Canada for 1,093 days (Impugned Decision, Certified Tribunal Record, at pp 13 and 15).

[23] 
  This is an unreasonable outcome which warrants the Court's intervention.

[24] 
  A Citizenship Judge is not entitled to simply waive the requirement of physical presence, as this would run contrary to the purpose of the Act ( 
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED). Moreover, this Court has found that a Citizenship Judge's "blending" of the citizenship test constitutes an error of law ( 
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED).

[25] 
  Justice Donald J. Rennie's reasoning in  
FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED, sheds light on Parliament's intent in legislating the residency requirements found in paragraph 5(1)( 
 c 
 ) of the Act: 
 
 
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED

[26] 
  Furthermore, as pointed out by Justice Peter B. Annis in  
FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED allowing the Citizenship Judge's reasoning to stand would render subsection 5(4) of the Act redundant: 
 
 
 
 FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED
 
 
 
 VIII.  
 Conclusion

[27] 
  For the reasons above, the Minister's application for judicial review is allowed.

[28] 
  The Court observes that the Respondent may re-apply for citizenship if she so wishes. 
 
 
 
 JUDGMENT

[29] 
   
 THIS COURT'S JUDGMENT is that 
  the application for judicial review is granted. There is no serious question of general importance to be certified. 
 
 
 
 Application granted.

statutes: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, SC 2001, c 27 (subsection 72(1))
legal_issues: The extent to which a decision-maker can deviate from statutorily prescribed residency requirements for naturalization.
The appropriate standard of review for a decision regarding fulfillment of residency requirements for naturalization.
Whether a decision-maker's interpretation of statutory residency requirements is reasonable.
The permissibility of waiving strict adherence to quantitative residency criteria in naturalization proceedings.
The relationship between different statutory provisions concerning residency and their potential for redundancy.
factual_background: A Russian citizen became a permanent resident of Canada on March 17, 2008.
An application for Canadian citizenship was filed on July 25, 2011.
The relevant residency period for the application was from July 25, 2007, to July 25, 2011.
A citizenship officer conducted an interview on February 25, 2013, and prepared a File Preparation and Analysis Template (FPAT).
A Citizenship Judge reviewed the application on December 29, 2014.
The FPAT noted a two-day shortfall in the required 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada.

The FPAT also identified an undeclared re-entry stamp to Canada dated April 10, 2009, an undeclared entry/exit stamp from Turkey, and other concerns regarding the applicant’s residence and employment history.
The Citizenship Judge determined the applicant was physically present in Canada for 1,093 days.
The Citizenship Judge granted Canadian citizenship to the applicant on December 31, 2014.
The applicant provided Notices of Assessment from Revenue Canada for most years within the relevant period.

Applicants: The Citizenship Judge erred in applying the physical presence test to determine residency.
The Citizenship Judge was not entitled to waive the requirement of physical presence, as it contradicts the purpose of the Act.
The Citizenship Judge's 'blending' of the citizenship test constitutes an error of law.
Allowing the Citizenship Judge's reasoning would render subsection 5(4) of the Act redundant.
The Respondent did not meet the 1,095-day physical presence requirement.
Respondents: The Citizenship Judge did not err in applying the physical presence test.
The Citizenship Judge did not fail to adequately assess the evidence, resulting in a reasonable finding of fact.

court_analysis: The court found the Citizenship Judge erred by effectively waiving the strict physical presence requirement of 1,095 days under s. 5(1)(c) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act. The court reasoned this approach contradicted the Act’s purpose.

The court clarified that while Citizenship Judges can choose among accepted citizenship tests, applying the physical presence test requires a quantitative assessment of days present, and the Judge’s acceptance of 1,093 days (two days short) was unreasonable.

The court emphasized that allowing a Judge to disregard the physical presence requirement would render s. 5(4) of the Act redundant, indicating a legislative intent for the requirement to be strictly applied.

The court relied on previous jurisprudence (specifically cited cases by Justices Rennie and Annis, though the full text of those cases isn't provided) to support the conclusion that Parliament intended a firm residency requirement, and that the physical presence test is more restrictive than other available tests.

The standard of review applied was reasonableness, but despite the deference typically given to Citizenship Judges, the court intervened because the Judge’s decision represented an unreasonable application of the law.
final_outcome: The application for judicial review is granted.
There is no serious question of general importance to be certified.
